statement.text: Steal syndrome (Hemodialysis Access-Induced Distal Ischemia - HAIDI) occurs when arteriovenous access diverts blood flow away from the hand, causing symptoms ranging from coolness to severe ischemic tissue loss.
statement.formal: Incidence: 1-5% of AVF, 5-10% of AVG; Risk factors: Diabetes, PAD, female, elderly, proximal access; Staging: HAIDI 1-4; Treatment: Banding, DRIL, RUDI, or ligation

explanation.intuition: The dialysis access creates a low-resistance pathway that 'steals' blood that would normally go to the hand. The more proximal the access, the greater the risk of starving the hand of blood.
explanation.key_insight: Steal syndrome is about both access flow and hand perfusion - some patients steal because the access flows too much, others because their hand has poor baseline perfusion.
explanation.technical_details: Dialysis access-induced hand ischemia results from arterial inflow being preferentially diverted into the low-resistance venous outflow of the access. Physiologic steal occurs in all functional accesses but becomes symptomatic when hand perfusion is inadequate. Risk factors include diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, female sex, elderly, and proximal access (brachial > radial). The HAIDI classification stages symptoms from mild pain (grade 1) to tissue loss (grade 4). Treatment options include access banding, DRIL procedure, RUDI, PAI, or access ligation.
common_misconceptions: All steal requires access ligation - FALSE, many can be managed with flow reduction
Steal only occurs with grafts - FALSE, can occur with any access, especially proximal fistulas
Cold hand means severe steal - FALSE, mild coolness is common and often tolerable
Steal always occurs immediately - FALSE, can develop months after access creation

grade_1.symptoms: Mild pain, no motor or sensory loss

grade_3.symptoms: Motor or sensory deficit, no tissue loss

studies.duplex: Assess access flow and arterial inflow

banding.technique: Narrowing access outflow to reduce flow

dril_procedure.name: Distal Revascularization - Interval Ligation
dril_procedure.technique: Bypass from proximal artery to distal brachial + ligate between

rudi.name: Revision Using Distal Inflow
rudi.technique: Move inflow to more distal artery

pai.name: Proximalization of Arterial Inflow
pai.technique: Use graft to bring inflow from more proximal artery

access_ligation.consequence: Loss of access, need for new site

definition.@value: Hand ischemia caused by diversion of arterial blood flow through dialysis access away from the distal extremity.

diagnosis: Clinical examination with access compression test
treatment: Access ligation if other measures fail

sources.reference: KDOQI Clinical Practice Guidelines for Vascular Access

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of dialysis access steal syndrome
Identify risk factors for steal syndrome development
Select appropriate treatment based on severity
clinical_pearls: Compression test: If symptoms improve with access compression, steal is confirmed
Proximal access = higher steal risk (brachial > radial)
DRIL preserves access while restoring hand perfusion
Diabetes and PAD are major risk factors
